Violation_Type: Failure to centralize life in Canada
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship judge erred in refusing Mr. Chen's application based on residential requirements and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Mr. Chen was 31 days short of the required 1095 days of residence; frequent trips abroad; lack of family or social ties in Canada
Remedy_Requested: Overturn of citizenship refusal, recognition of eligibility
Court_Ruling: The judge's decision was reasonable; Mr. Chen did not meet residency requirements or demonstrate a centralized mode of existence in Canada
Defendant_Behavior: Refusal of citizenship application by Citizenship judge
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient physical presence in Canada, lack of integration or connection to Canada
Legal_Standard: Residency requirement of 1095 days within four years; 'centralized mode of existence' test
Assessment_Factor: Duration of residence, frequency of travel abroad, family and social ties in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in the judge's assessment
Evidence_Used: Residency records, travel history, personal ties in Canada
Application_Basis: Accumulation of 1095 days of residence and demonstration of life centered in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Travel patterns, absence of family or community connections in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicants must have 1095 days of residence and show their life is centralized in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence of residency and integration into Canadian society
Cause_Description: Mr. Chen's application was refused due to insufficient residency and failure to centralize his life in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Residency and travel evidence reviewed; credibility of claims assessed
Evidence_Issues: Disputed interpretation of time spent in Canada and significance of international travel
Residency_Compliance: Not met – 31 days short of 1095-day requirement
Evidence_Assessment: Judge found Mr. Chen’s life was not centered in Canada based on travel and lack of ties
Decision_Rationale: Mr. Chen failed to meet statutory residency requirement and did not demonstrate a centralized mode of existence in Canada
Evidentiary_Issues: Inadequate documentation or proof of continuous residence and integration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard on judicial review; substantive residency and centrality tests
